article_metadata.description: Obamacare is kind of like an elaborate spaceship circling a black hole. It's a complex and desperate effort to avoid falling into the black hole of an adverse selection death spiral in which insurance markets inescapably collapse as only the sickest individuals seek coverage. One of the ACA's least understood and least publicized components to keep the spaceship out of the black hole is Risk Adjustment (section 1343, 42 USC § 18063). This program decouples the amount the individual and government pay in premiums from the amount the insurer receives. Under Risk Adjustment, insurers get paid extra for insuring risky insureds, even if the gross premiums paid by or on behalf of those risky insureds are no higher than for those less risky receiving the same contract. In recent weeks, the Risk Adjustment component has been jeopardized by an unexpected threat: a rebellion from at least some of the states. That attack perhaps unwittingly exposes the constitutional fragility of the whole program. If successful, the states' attack on Risk Adjustment could place our Obamacare spaceship on a more perilous trajectory.
article_metadata.author: The Apothecary
